#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Bendigo
#Text=Bendigo is a regional city in
#Text=Victoria , Australia .
#Text=With a population of about 92,000 it is the 4th largest city in the State .
#Text=Bendigo is about 140 km ( 105 miles , 1½ hour 's drive ) north-north-west of Melbourne .
#Text=It is known for its grand Victorian architecture , built during the gold rush of the mid-19th century .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Bendigo grew to a bustling town after gold was discovered in the area in 1851 .
#Text=The wealth of this period resulted in the construction of many fine public and commercial buildings in the city centre , as well as private homes in the surrounding residential areas .
#Text=The population of the Greater Bendigo municipality ( which includes much rural area and the nearby towns of Heathcote and Elmore ) is over 110,000 , as of 2016 .
#Text=Despite this it retains a friendly country atmosphere .
#Text=The town has far less rain than Melbourne due to its position to the north of the Great Dividing Range .
#Text=Summers are hot and dry , up to 40 °C or more on some days .
#Text=Winters tend to be mild ; with lowest temperatures around -5 °C overnight and around 15 °C during the day .
#Text=Sheep , cattle , fruit , wine and cereal crops are the most common products of the area .
#Text=Gold is being discovered again in large quantities at deeper levels in the old mines with new technology .
#Text=History
#Text=Before European settlement the area was occupied by the clans of the Dja Dja Wurrung people .
#Text=They were regarded by other tribes as being a superior people , not only because of their rich hunting grounds but because from their area came a greenstone rock for their stone axes .
#Text=Early Europeans described the Dja Dja Wrung as a strong , physically well-developed people and not belligerent .
#Text=Nevertheless the early years of European settlement in the Mount Alexander area were bloodied by many clashes between intruder and dispossessed .
#Text=Major Mitchell passed through the area in 1836 .
#Text=Following his discovery , the first squatters arrived in 1840 to establish vast sheep runs .
#Text=Bendigo Creek was part of the Mount Alexander or Ravenswood sheep run .

#Text=It is generally acknowledged that Mrs John Kennedy and Mrs Patrick Farrell , wives of workmen on the Ravenswood run , found gold at ‘ The Rocks ’ - now an identified location that can be visited at the junction of Bendigo Creek and Maple Street .
#Text=The first ‘ rush ’ took place in November 1851 when miners at Castlemaine ( Forest Creek ) heard of the new discovery .

#Text=Alluvial gold was found in the area of its first discovery ( present day Golden Square ) and then the miners followed the gold down the creek to what is now Epsom and up the creek to the present suburb of Kangaroo Flat .
#Text=Further discoveries were soon made in the tributary creeks at Eaglehawk and Diamond Hill .

#Text=As a result of the rush of people to the area , the Gold Commissioner ’s Office , the Police Barracks and the courts were erected on Camp Hill , now the present Rosalind Park in central Bendigo .

#Text=The “ diggers ” , as the miners were called , numbered as high as thirty thousand and came from all over the world ; from England , Wales , Scotland , Ireland – along with Germans , Italians , Swiss , French and Americans .
#Text=The Chinese population reached many thousands in the early gold rush period but their numbers dropped rapidly as the nineteenth century progressed .
#Text=Bendigo quickly grew from a “ city of tents ” to become a substantial city with great public buildings .
#Text=The first hospital was built in 1853 and the first town plan was developed by 1854 .
#Text=A municipality emerged and the first Town Hall was commissioned in 1859 .
#Text=Bendigo was connected to Melbourne by telegraph in 1857 and it was from here that the first message reporting the deaths of Burke and Wills was sent in 1861 .
#Text=Frequent Cobb & Co coaches ran to Melbourne until the railway reached Bendigo in 1862 .
#Text=In the following decade it made the transition from small mining town to large and wealthy city , and becoming established as a key centre for surrounding settlements .
#Text=Water supply was always a problem in Bendigo .
#Text=This was partly solved with a system harnessing the waters of the Coliban River , designed by engineer Joseph Brady .
#Text=Water first flowed through the viaduct in 1877 .
#Text=Architect William Charles Vahland left a major mark on Bendigo during this period .

#Text=He is credited as innovating what was the most popular residential design of the period , low cost cottages with verandahs decorated in iron lace which became a popular style right across Victoria .

#Text=He transformed the Bendigo Town Hall between 1878 to 1886 into a grand building and designed more than eighty more public and private buildings , including the Alexandra Fountain , the Masonic Temple ( now the Capital Theatre ) and the Mechanics Institute and School of Mines ( now the Bendigo Regional Institute of TAFE ) , ' Fortuna Villa ' in Golden Square , ( which was the home of ' Quartz King ' George Lansell ) , the Law Courts , former Post Office and the expanded Shamrock Hotel in Pall Mall .
#Text=A tram network began in 1890 and was used for public transport .
#Text=By car
#Text=Bendigo is just over 1½ hours drive north of Melbourne on the Calder Freeway ( Highway ) .
#Text=The freeway is all dual carriageway .
#Text=If you are coming from Sydney , take the Shepparton exit from the Hume Freeway , and then follow the signs from Shepparton to Bendigo .
#Text=By plane
#Text=While Bendigo does have a small airport , it will likely be much more convenient to fly into Melbourne .
#Text=From there , hire a car and take the M79 ( Calder Freeway ) which starts just by the airport .
#Text=If you do not wish to drive , take the Skybus into Southern Cross Station and get the train to Bendigo .
#Text=Alternatively take the shuttle direct to Bendigo from the airport .
#Text=For a cheaper option , catch a 479 to Sunbury Station and get the train to Bendigo .
#Text=By train
#Text=Bendigo is served by trains which run from Melbourne 's Southern Cross Station into the south of Bendigo .
#Text=These usually run about once an hour .
#Text=The journey takes approximately two hours from Melbourne .
#Text=As the route is used by many commuters , trains may be more crowded in the early morning and late afternoon/early evening on weekdays .
#Text=From the station , most of the CBD is within walking distance .
#Text=Alternatively buses run into the centre of the city and other parts of Bendigo from the station .
#Text=Vline also operates a coach twice daily from Adelaide direct to Bendigo .
